subject: Cooking
title: Food and Memory: Proust's Madeleine Effect
description: A short lesson to help you apply Food and Memory: Proust's Madeleine Effect.

hook.text: Marcel Proust bit into a madeleine cake and suddenly relived his entire childhood. Neuroscience explains why.

buildup.text: Smell and taste bypass the thalamus and connect directly to the hippocampus and amygdala ‚Äî memory centers.

discovery.text: No other sense has this direct route. That's why food memories feel more vivid and emotional than visual ones.

twist.text: Even foods you haven't eaten in decades can trigger detailed memories when tasted again unexpectedly.

climax.text: Hospitals use familiar food aromas to help dementia patients retrieve otherwise inaccessible memories.

punchline.text: A flavor can unlock a memory that no photograph can.

quiz.question: Why do food-triggered memories feel especially vivid?
options: We eat more often than we see
Smell connects directly to memory centers
